newsitem.title: UK: Rangebound bourses cool on second U.S. raid.
newsitem.headline: Rangebound bourses cool on second U.S. raid.

text.p: European financial markets took news of a second U.S. attack on Iraq in their stride on Wednesday, marking stocks higher, the dollar steady and gold lower.
British shares, buoyed by a rebound in Wall Street stocks and bonds overnight, held opening gains which reversed the bulk of their previous day's losses.
An agreed 264 million pound ($412.1 million) bid by food distributor Booker for food wholesaler Nurdin & Peacock also helped sentiment, sending the blue chip FTSE 100 index up 25 points.
Yet traders said the London market was likely to be quiet ahead of Wednesday's monetary meeting between Governor of the Bank of England Eddie George and finance minister Kenneth Clarke.
German shares hovered at higher levels mid way through bourse trade but were off earlier peaks.
Dealers said that trade was likely to be steady, but the focus was definitely on key U.S. non-farm payroll data for August due on Friday, which could set the tone for U.S. interest rates.
In Paris, French stocks also opened higher, helped by firmer bond prices and Wall Street's strong close.

Oil stocks Total and Elf-Aquitaine, which have risen on the back of higher oil prices, extended their gains after Total confirmed investor expectations of good results by reporting a 45 percent jump in its first-half profit.
The CAC-40 index was up around 15 points, but still below the 2,000 level.
In currencies, the dollar was slightly firmer against the mark and off its earlier lows against the yen in a quiet European midsession.

Dealers said market attention had shifted from the U.S. attacks in Iraq to Thursday's German GDP data and, more importantly, Friday's U.S. jobs figures against a backdrop of growing expectations of higher U.S. rates near-term.

"It's a waiting game now until Friday, no one's willing to stick their neck out ahead of the payrolls," said a dealer at a U.S. bank here. "The Iraq story is still there but it's been moved very much in the background now."
Against the yen, the dollar was firmer from earlier levels but just below 109 yen.

The yen was also firmer against the mark as the initial impact of the U.S./Iraq tensions faded and earlier concerns eased over the effect of higher oil prices on Japan and its high dependency on dollar priced oil imports.
CURRENCIES AT 1100 GMT
The dollar was trading at 1.4856 marks and 108.95 yen after 1.4837 marks and 109.25 yen on Tuesday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 1100 GMT
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares was up 23.3 points at 3,879.2.
Frankfurt's 30-share DAX index was 21.16 up at 2,532.37. The IBIS DAX was up 4.90 at 2,533.63.
In Paris, the CAC-40 share index was up 15.56 at 1,987.10.
PRECIOUS METALS

Gold fixed at $385.95 against $386.60 on Tuesday afternoon and $387.20 in the morning. It dipped below $386 on London-based selling after showing little initial reaction to the second missile attack by the U.S. on Iraq. Silver was lower with gold at $5.15, down three cents. Platinum was off $1.00 at $394.75.
